instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
can you tell me what is  
<SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL>
and  <SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL>
also can I measure 12mhz using dso

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
These are the SMC connections to external quartz crystal.
It gives better stability to its internal oscillator.
An o-scope can show the exact 12MHz wave, but is not really required.
If you check more working boards, will see there is 1-1.2V DC level, when the oscillation is present.

In similar manner, 32.768KHz crystal can be considered in good working state, if 0.45V DC level is detected on it; valid for Macbook boards!
The o-scope is almost obsolete in the laptop repairs.
Do not believe any super-youtube-technician which presume the use of expensive o-scope for this purpose.
DC voltage measurements help more, when you get experience.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
32.768 OK WHEN PLUGGING 
But I didn't get anything on <SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Did you check DC level too?
What about other power rails and signals of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2), at page 37?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: all other <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> required voltages including vddc ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present?
No 12MHz pulse detected when pressing power button?

What is the actual problem of your machine?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
just pulsing all voltages
when I removed u 1950 all voltages except V core stands stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
So 12MHz oscillator is OK.

Resolder <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>; test again the board.
VCORE pulsing too?
Check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> also.
Test starting in SMC bypass mode.

Try to post accurate information.
Voltages pulsing 1, 2 times, or every few seconds?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
voltage pulsing 2 times
VCORE pulsing too
also <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
in normal condition

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Resoldered <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> all pulsing but core voltage not coming

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
We discussed many times two pulses symptom on 00165 board.
You should know all to check now.
It is the worst scenario for this board...
